Award.AwardTitle: CI-ADDO-NEW: Collaborative Research: Development of DARwIn Humanoid Robots for Research, Education and Outreach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops the DARwIn-miniature-humanoid-robot platform with advance computational power, sophisticated sensors, high payload capacity, and dynamic motion ability to enable many exciting research, education, and outreach activities. Two models of DARwIn robot, DARwIn-HP (High Performance) and DARwIn-LC (Low Cost), will be designed, fabricated, and built for distribution to 11 partner universities (including major research universities, RUI institutions, a women's college, and two local high schools) to establish a humanoid-robotics community. The project engages the humanoid-robotics community in a concerted effort to advance humanoid robotics.

The research results from the humanoid-robotics community will find applications in assistive robotics technology for the elderly, intelligent humanoids, and homeland security and the military. The partner universities will utilize DARwIn robots in their classroom teaching and projects as well as outreach activities to recruit high-school students and encourage them to select computer science or engineering for their career choices. An annual workshop will be organized and a website will be developed to broaden the DARwIn project and disseminate results. Public demonstrations of the robots at various high-impact events such as FIRST robotics competitions will capture the minds of K-12 students and promote interest in computer science and engineering among them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Dynamic Anthropomorphic Robot with Intelligence (DARwIn) was initiated by the Robotics and Mechanisms Laboratory (RoMeLa), now at UCLA to utilize DARwIn robots in a concerted effort to engage a diverse group of next-generation computer scientists and engineers in research, education and outreach activities. Humanoid research platforms that are commercially available are often expensive and difficult to modify or cheap but limited in functionality. The mechanical design of DARwIn-OP (Open Platform) features a system of modular components that are relatively easy to produce using machining or rapid prototyping techniques or purchased from vendors. All fabrication, assembly, and software instruction manuals and data are available online for free to foster community collaboration and user information exchange. Additionally, participating in relevant venues in robotics competition has provided better exposure to the community and the feedbacks gathered during and after the venues have been used to improve the performance and evaluate the successfulness of the project.

 

To share all the exciting experience and outcomes using DARwIn platforms from different perspectives, we have invited thirteen partner universities, who had been using DARwIn robots in their institutions, to a workshop titled, “Humanoid Robots for Research, Education, and Outreach” held at the ASME 2014 International Design & Engineering Technical Conferences and Computers & Information in Engineering Conference (IDETC/CIE) on Aug 17, 2014 in Buffalo, New York. While all representatives from their respective universities reported consistent and ongoing educational outreach activities, recruiting anywhere between 100 and 400 people per year, the distinct contribution of each institutions in robotics research can be summarized as followed: A representative from University of Pennsylvania presented a work on developing software libraries for the DARwIn-OP. Virginia Tech representative unveiled some updates on design and manufacturing improvements of the DARwIn-HP, prior to its release to partner universities. Representatives from other institutions, including Purdue University, and Georgia Institute of Technology cited their interactive studies using DARwIn robots. Purdue explored the topic of artificial intelligence and its basic application, such as role-based game playing, while Georgia Tech investigated the topic of simulation versus embodied agents in terms of physical therapeutic assistance.  As the PI have moved institutions from Virginia Tech to UCLA, some complications and delays have risen from the project transfer, so the workshop could not have settled as an annual tradition but sharing outcomes among the partner universities still persist.

 

Aside from the research projects conducted at the original fourteen partner universities in the U.S., there are many other comprehensive studies conducted in research labs around the world. Since 2006, more than fifty scholarly articles have been published in peer-reviewed journals, conference proceedings, and others, in a consistent manner. About forty percent of these articles were from the field of computer science engineering, confirming DARwIn’s feasibility as a computer science research platform. Each of these studies had directly dealt with DARwIn robot to explore their research topics ranging from computational biology to interactive psychotherapy. Recent studies on locomotion control, vision-based motion planning, coordination, and control, and energy management of overall system using DARwIn robots have furthered these research studies in different degrees and in various forms.
